result.test_plan: --Confirm that there are no monitoring alerts for the router
result.implementation_plan:
-- Place router into maintenance mode in the monitoring platform
-- Logon to router through SSH
-- Run the following command

router(config-router)#router bgp 12345
router(config-router)#neighbor {neighbor ip} soft-reconfig [inbound]
router#clear ip bgp {neighbor ip} soft in

-- Confirm the sessions have been cleared
-- Place router back into operational mode in the monitoring platform
result.short_description: Clear BGP sessions on a Cisco router
result.backout_plan:
Due to the limited number of commands in the implementation plan it is not possible to backout the change.

If required you are authorized to reboot the router if BGP fails to work
result.description:
Resend the complete BGP table to neighboring routers

--Both neighbors need to support soft reset route refresh capability.
--Stores complete BGP table of you neighbor in router memory.
--Not a good idea on a peering router with full feed, due to the memory requirements.
Please roll-back SP2 patch for all XP Users.

result.test_plan:
-- Run connectivity tests by connecting laptop to copper interface
-- Ensure that switch is showing as healthy in network monitoring console
result.implementation_plan:
-- Physically rack switch in top of cabinet
-- Ensure that redundant power supply is connected to the backup power circuit in the cabinet
-- Ensure that first GBIC fibre connector (Gi0/1) connects to primary distribution switch
-- Ensure that second GBIC fibre connector (Gi1/1) connects to secondary distribution switch
-- Connect console port to cabinet management console
-- Add switch to network management console
-- Add switch to network monitoring console
-- Add switch to ServiceNow CMDB
result.backout_plan:
-- Physically remove switch and all associated cabling
-- Remove switch from management, monitoring and ServiceNow CMDB
result.description: This standard change template describes adding a new network switch to a datacenter cabinet

result.test_plan: Run the "show vlan 101" command to view the new configuration (changing 101 for the correct VLAN number)
result.implementation_plan:
--Logon to the switch using SSH
--Type the following commands

switch# configure terminal
switch(config)# interface {type slot/port | port-channel number}
switch(config-if)# switchport access vlan vlan-id

For example

switch# configure terminal
switch(config)# interface Gi1/1
switch(config-if)# switchport access vlan 101

--Save the switch config file
result.short_description: Change VLAN on a Cisco switchport
result.backout_plan: Check the previous version of the switchport config in the configuration management database and revert
result.description: Change the port of a Cisco switch to a new VLAN. This would commonly occur when moving a server from one IP network to another.

result.test_plan:
--No client issues result from the removal of this DC
--All references to this DC have been removed from Active Directory
--All references to this DC have been removed from DNS
--All references to this DC have been removed from anti-virus, endpoint management, monitoring and ServiceNow CMDB
result.implementation_plan:
--Inform local IT of the necessary steps to change DHCP and static IP clients to use a different DC/DNS servers for name resolution
--Use Network Monitor to check if any DNS queries are being received by the DC before demoting, reconfigure any requestors DNS before continuing
--Notify the Operations Teams about the demotion via email
--Place the DC in outage mode in monitoring tools
--Run the AD DC Demotion Preparation tool in management tools
--Logon to the DC to be removed from Active Directory--Run DCPROMO to uninstall AD and reboot
--Uninstall DNS
--Remove the server from the domain by joining it to a workgroup and reboot
--Logon to a regional hub DC in the same domain as the DC that was removed
--Delete the computer object
--Delete any leftover DNS records
--Locate the DNS zone for the domain and then right-click it and select properties
--Click the name servers tab
--Locate and delete the entry for the removed DNS server (if present)
--Delete the server object in AD Sites and Services
--Logon to a forest root DC
--launch the DNS console on the forest root DC
--locate and delete all DNS records that point to the removed DC in the _msdcs zone and in any child zones of it 
--Also verify that no record exists in the delegated zone for the child domain zone
--Create requests to remove device from anti-virus, endpoint management, monitoring and ServiceNow CMDB
result.backout_plan: Due to the nature of this procedure any means to back out of this after the process has begun should not be implemented. Any type of recovery from backup or any other tool could cause corruption to the Active Directory database and could cause more harm than good. Once the implementation plan has been started it will need to be carried out completely.
result.description: Decommission a server from use including removal from backup, systems management and monitoring systems and disposal of hardware

result.test_plan: --Confirm that there are no monitoring alerts for the router
result.implementation_plan:
-- Place router into maintenance mode in the monitoring platform
-- Logon to router through SSH
-- Run the following command

router(config-router)#router bgp 12345
router(config-router)#neighbor {neighbor ip} soft-reconfig [inbound]
router#clear ip bgp {neighbor ip} soft in

-- Confirm the sessions have been cleared
-- Place router back into operational mode in the monitoring platform
result.short_description: Clear BGP sessions on a Cisco router
result.backout_plan:
Due to the limited number of commands in the implementation plan it is not possible to backout the change.

If required you are authorized to reboot the router if BGP fails to work
result.description:
Resend the complete BGP table to neighboring routers

--Both neighbors need to support soft reset route refresh capability.
--Stores complete BGP table of you neighbor in router memory.
--Not a good idea on a peering router with full feed, due to the memory requirements.

result.test_plan: Ensure that the monitoring console is all green for this server before closing change request
result.implementation_plan:
--In the server monitoring console set the server to "Maintenance mode" to prevent alerts being sent
--If the server has network attached storage (NFS or iSCSI) stop any file server applications and unmount the storage
--Reboot the server4. Check the Windows system log for any error messages
--In the server monitoring console set the server back to "Operational" mode
result.backout_plan: There is no backout plan for this change template
result.description: Reboot a Windows Server (after patching or to clear a fault) making sure that it is removed from monitoring alerts, that network attached storage is unmounted and that it restarts cleanly

result.short_description: Switch Sales over to the new 555 prefix
result.description:
Sales has their own private dialing prefix now so they'll
            always have an open outside line even if the PBX is full.

result.implementation_plan:
login to unix 201 as root
append ipaddress 192.168.1.254
Restart network with /etc/init.d/network restart
test network connectivity using ping 192.168.1.254
test network connectivity using ping 10.10.100.10
result.backout_plan:
revert to default gateway 192.168.1.100
Restart network with /etc/init.d/network restart
test network connectivity using ping 192.168.1.254
test network connectivity using ping 10.10.100.10

result.implementation_plan:
vi /etc/network/interfaces
insert line:
dns-nameservers 8.8.8.8 8.8.4.4
:wq
test name resolution using command: host www.google.com
result.backout_plan: Comment out new line in /etc/network/interfaces
result.description: We need to add additional redundant name servers to lnux100, lnux101 and PS LinuxApp01

Remove existing Cisco 2900 from network

Reprovision existing Cisco 2900 switch
Validate connectivity from all private networks
result.description: The existing Cisco 2900 is being decommissioned and replaced with a Cisco 4500 that supports additional services and is still supported by Cisco.

result.implementation_plan:
vi initSAPORA01.ora
yank and put existing db_block_buffers line
Comment out existing db_block_buffers setting
Set new db_block_buffers line to 7500
Restart SAPORA01 database instance
result.backout_plan: rollback to existing db_block_buffer setting
result.description: The database size has increased and the cache hit rate is at the low end of an acceptable rate. The Database team needss to increase the amount of memory allocated to the Oracle SGA to increase the cache hit rate.

            our end to support them, what it would cost to install them, and how
            fast the whole thing could happen.

result.change_plan:
Backup dataset, image current system, reinstall previous
            release, test
result.backout_plan:
Current prod environment to be snapshotted with VmWare
            prior to change.
result.description:
Performance of the Siebel SFA software has been severely
            degraded since the upgrade performed this weekend.

            We moved to an unsupported Oracle DB version. Need to rollback the
            Oracle Instance to a supported version.

result.test_plan:
-- Run connectivity tests by connecting laptop to copper interface
-- Ensure that switch is showing as healthy in network monitoring console
result.implementation_plan:
-- Physically rack switch in top of cabinet
-- Ensure that redundant power supply is connected to the backup power circuit in the cabinet
-- Ensure that first GBIC fibre connector (Gi0/1) connects to primary distribution switch
-- Ensure that second GBIC fibre connector (Gi1/1) connects to secondary distribution switch
-- Connect console port to cabinet management console
-- Add switch to network management console
-- Add switch to network monitoring console
-- Add switch to ServiceNow CMDB
result.backout_plan:
-- Physically remove switch and all associated cabling
-- Remove switch from management, monitoring and ServiceNow CMDB
result.description: This standard change template describes adding a new network switch to a datacenter cabinet

result.implementation_plan:
vi initSAPORA01.ora
yank and put existing db_block_buffers line
Comment out existing db_block_buffers setting
Set new db_block_buffers line to 7500
Restart SAPORA01 database instance
result.backout_plan: rollback to existing db_block_buffer setting
result.description: The database size has increased and the cache hit rate is at the low end of an acceptable rate. The Database team needss to increase the amount of memory allocated to the Oracle SGA to increase the cache hit rate.

result.test_plan:
Read through the README file included with the patch and
            test applying the patch or patchset in a non-production environment
            prior to applying it in production.
result.change_plan:
* Download the patch from Metalink.
            * Unzip it on the
            database server.
            * Shut down all databases using the Oracle9i home.
            *
            Apply the patchset to the Oracle binaries.
            * Start up all databases
            using the Oracle9i home and run required SQL
            scripts within each
            database.
result.backout_plan:
* Shut down the database
            * Change Oracle Home to the old
            one
            * Start the database
result.description:
Need to apply the follow security patches from oracle -
            10.2.0.1 to 10.2.0.3.

login to unix 201 as root
append ipaddress 192.168.1.254

test network connectivity using ping 192.168.1.254
test network connectivity using ping 10.10.100.10
result.backout_plan:
revert to default gateway 192.168.1.100
Restart network with /etc/init.d/network restart
test network connectivity using ping 192.168.1.254
test network connectivity using ping 10.10.100.10
